summary.long: Ecclesiastes is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: Words of a preacher, son of David, king in Jerusalem:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Vanity of vanities, said the Preacher, Vanity of vanities: the whole [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What advantage [is] to man by all his labour that he laboureth at under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A generation is going, and a generation is coming, and the earth to the age is standing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, the sun hath risen, and the sun hath gone in, and unto its place panting it is rising there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Going unto the south, and turning round unto the north, turning round, turning round, the wind is going, and by its circuits the wind hath returned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the streams are going unto the sea, and the sea is not full; unto a place whither the streams are going, thither they are turning back to go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All these things are wearying; a man is not able to speak, the eye is not satisfied by seeing, nor filled is the ear from hearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What [is] that which hath been? it [is] that which is, and what [is] that which hath been done? it [is] that which is done, and there is not an entirely new thing under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is a thing of which [one] saith: `See this, it [is] new!' already it hath been in the ages that were before us!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is not a remembrance of former [generations]; and also of the latter that are, there is no remembrance of them with those that are at the last.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, a preacher, have been king over Israel in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I have given my heart to seek and to search out by wisdom concerning all that hath been done under the heavens. It [is] a sad travail God hath given to the sons of man to be humbled by it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen all the works that have been done under the sun, and lo, the whole [is] vanity and vexation of spirit!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A crooked thing [one] is not able to make straight, and a lacking thing is not able to be numbered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I -- I spake with my heart, saying, `I, lo, I have magnified and added wisdom above every one who hath been before me at Jerusalem, and my heart hath seen abundantly wisdom and knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I give my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly: I have known that even this [is] vexation of spirit;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for, in abundance of wisdom [is] abundance of sadness, and he who addeth knowledge addeth pain.'
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said in my heart, `Pray, come, I try thee with mirth, and look thou on gladness;' and lo, even it [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Of laughter I said, `Foolish!' and of mirth, `What [is] this it is doing?'
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have sought in my heart to draw out with wine my appetite, (and my heart leading in wisdom), and to take hold on folly till that I see where [is] this -- the good to the sons of man of that which they do under the heavens, the number of the days of their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made great my works, I builded for me houses, I planted for me vineyards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made for me gardens and paradises, and I planted in them trees of every fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made for me pools of water, to water from them a forest shooting forth trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I got men-servants, and maid-servants, and sons of the house were to me; also, I had much substance -- herd and flock -- above all who had been before me in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gathered for me also silver and gold, and the peculiar treasure of kings and of the provinces. I prepared for me men-singers and women-singers, and the luxuries of the sons of man -- a wife and wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I became great, and increased above every one who had been before me in Jerusalem; also, my wisdom stood with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all that mine eyes asked I kept not back from them; I withheld not my heart from any joy, for my heart rejoiced because of all my labour, and this hath been my portion, from all my labour,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I have looked on all my works that my hands have done, and on the labour that I have laboured to do, and lo, the whole [is] vanity and vexation of spirit, and there is no advantage under the sun!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I turned to see wisdom, and madness, and folly, but what [is] the man who cometh after the king? that which [is] already -- they have done it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I saw that there is an advantage to wisdom above folly, like the advantage of the light above the darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wise! -- his eyes [are] in his head, and the fool in darkness is walking, and I also knew that one event happeneth with them all;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I said in my heart, `As it happeneth with the fool, it happeneth also with me, and why am I then more wise?' And I spake in my heart, that also this [is] vanity:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That there is no remembrance to the wise -- with the fool -- to the age, for that which [is] already, [in] the days that are coming is all forgotten, and how dieth the wise? with the fool!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I have hated life, for sad to me [is] the work that hath been done under the sun, for the whole [is] vanity and vexation of spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I have hated all my labour that I labour at under the sun, because I leave it to a man who is after me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And who knoweth whether he is wise or foolish? yet he doth rule over all my labour that I have laboured at, and that I have done wisely under the sun! this also [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I turned round to cause my heart to despair concerning all the labour that I laboured at under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there is a man whose labour [is] in wisdom, and in knowledge, and in equity, and to a man who hath not laboured therein he giveth it -- his portion! Even this [is] vanity and a great evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For what hath been to a man by all his labour, and by the thought of his heart that he laboured at under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For all his days are sorrows, and his travail sadness; even at night his heart hath not lain down; this also [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is nothing good in a man who eateth, and hath drunk, and hath shewn his soul good in his labour. This also I have seen that it [is] from the hand of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For who eateth and who hasteth out more than I?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For to a man who [is] good before Him, He hath given wisdom, and knowledge, and joy; and to a sinner He hath given travail, to gather and to heap up, to give to the good before God. Even this [is] vanity and vexation of spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To everything -- a season, and a time to every delight under the heavens:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A time to bring forth, And a time to die. A time to plant, And a time to eradicate the planted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A time to slay, And a time to heal, A time to break down, And a time to build up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A time to weep, And a time to laugh. A time to mourn, And a time to skip.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A time to cast away stones, And a time to heap up stones. A time to embrace, And a time to be far from embracing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A time to seek, And a time to destroy. A time to keep, And a time to cast away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A time to rend, And a time to sew. A time to be silent, And a time to speak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A time to love, And a time to hate. A time of war, And a time of peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What advantage hath the doer in that which he is labouring at?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen the travail that God hath given to the sons of man to be humbled by it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole He hath made beautiful in its season; also, that knowledge He hath put in their heart without which man findeth not out the work that God hath done from the beginning even unto the end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have known that there is no good for them except to rejoice and to do good during their life,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: yea, even every man who eateth and hath drunk and seen good by all his labour, it [is] a gift of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have known that all that God doth is to the age, to it nothing is to be added, and from it nothing is to be withdrawn; and God hath wrought that they do fear before Him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What is that which hath been? already it is, and that which [is] to be hath already been, and God requireth that which is pursued.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And again, I have seen under the sun the place of judgment -- there [is] the wicked; and the place of righteousness -- there [is] the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said in my heart, `The righteous and the wicked doth God judge, for a time [is] to every matter and for every work there.'
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said in my heart concerning the matter of the sons of man that God might cleanse them, so as to see that they themselves [are] beasts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For an event [is to] the sons of man, and an event [is to] the beasts, even one event [is] to them; as the death of this, so [is] the death of that; and one spirit [is] to all, and the advantage of man above the beast is nothing, for the whole [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole are going unto one place, the whole have been from the dust, and the whole are turning back unto the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who knoweth the spirit of the sons of man that is going up on high, and the spirit of the beast that is going down below to the earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I have seen that there is nothing better than that man rejoice in his works, for it [is] his portion; for who doth bring him in to look on that which is after him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I have turned, and I see all the oppressions that are done under the sun, and lo, the tear of the oppressed, and they have no comforter; and at the hand of their oppressors [is] power, and they have no comforter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I am praising the dead who have already died above the living who are yet alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And better than both of them [is] he who hath not yet been, in that he hath not seen the evil work that hath been done under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I have seen all the labour, and all the benefit of the work, because for it a man is the envy of his neighbour. Even this [is] vanity and vexation of spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fool is clasping his hands, and eating his own flesh:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: `Better [is] a handful [with] quietness, than two handfuls [with] labour and vexation of spirit.'
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I have turned, and I see a vain thing under the sun:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is one, and there is not a second; even son or brother he hath not, and there is no end to all his labour! His eye also is not satisfied with riches, and [he saith not], `For whom am I labouring and bereaving my soul of good?' This also is vanity, it is a sad travail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two [are] better than the one, in that they have a good reward by their labour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For if they fall, the one raiseth up his companion, but wo to the one who falleth and there is not a second to raise him up!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, if two lie down, then they have heat, but how hath one heat?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if the one strengthen himself, the two stand against him; and the threefold cord is not hastily broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better is a poor and wise youth than an old and foolish king, who hath not known to be warned any more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For from a house of prisoners he hath come out to reign, for even in his own kingdom he hath been poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen all the living, who are walking under the sun, with the second youth who doth stand in his place;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: there is no end to all the people, to all who were before them; also, the latter rejoice not in him. Surely this also is vanity and vexation of spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Keep thy feet when thou goest unto a house of God, and draw near to hear rather than to give of fools the sacrifice, for they do not know they do evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cause not thy mouth to hasten, and let not thy heart hasten to bring out a word before God, for God is in the heavens, and thou on the earth, therefore let thy words be few.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the dream hath come by abundance of business, and the voice of a fool by abundance of words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When thou vowest a vow to God, delay not to complete it, for there is no pleasure in fools; that which thou vowest -- complete.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better that thou do not vow, than that thou dost vow and dost not complete.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suffer not thy mouth to cause thy flesh to sin, nor say before the messenger, that `it [is] an error,' why is God wroth because of thy voice, and hath destroyed the work of thy hands?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For, in the abundance of dreams both vanities and words abound; but fear thou God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If oppression of the poor, and violent taking away of judgment and righteousness thou seest in a province, do not marvel at the matter, for a higher than the high is observing, and high ones [are] over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the abundance of a land is for all. A king for a field is served.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoso is loving silver is not satisfied [with] silver, nor he who is in love with stores [with] increase. Even this [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the multiplying of good have its consumers been multiplied, and what benefit [is] to its possessor except the sight of his eyes?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sweet [is] the sleep of the labourer whether he eat little or much; and the sufficiency of the wealthy is not suffering him to sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is a painful evil I have seen under the sun: wealth kept for its possessor, for his evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And that wealth hath been lost in an evil business, and he hath begotten a son and there is nothing in his hand!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he came out from the belly of his mother, naked he turneth back to go as he came, and he taketh not away anything of his labour, that doth go in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And this also [is] a painful evil, just as he came, so he goeth, and what advantage [is] to him who laboureth for wind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also all his days in darkness he consumeth, and sadness, and wrath, and sickness abound.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lo, that which I have seen: [It is] good, because beautiful, to eat, and to drink, and to see good in all one's labour that he laboureth at under the sun, the number of the days of his life that God hath given to him, for it [is] his portion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every man also to whom God hath given wealth and riches, and hath given him power to eat of it, and to accept his portion, and to rejoice in his labour, this is a gift of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he doth not much remember the days of his life, for God is answering through the joy of his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is an evil that I have seen under the sun, and it [is] great on man:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man to whom God giveth wealth, and riches, and honour, and there is no lack to his soul of all that he desireth, and God giveth him not power to eat of it, but a stranger eateth it; this [is] vanity, and it [is] an evil disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man doth beget a hundred, and live many years, and is great, because they are the days of his years, and his soul is not satisfied from the goodness, and also he hath not had a grave, I have said, `Better than he [is] the untimely birth.'
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For in vanity he came in, and in darkness he goeth, and in darkness his name is covered,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even the sun he hath not seen nor known, more rest hath this than that.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And though he had lived a thousand years twice over, yet good he hath not seen; to the same place doth not every one go?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the labour of man [is] for his mouth, and yet the soul is not filled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For what advantage [is] to the wise above the fool? What to the poor who knoweth to walk before the living?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better [is] the sight of the eyes than the going of the soul. This also [is] vanity and vexation of spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What [is] that which hath been? already is its name called, and it is known that it [is] man, and he is not able to contend with him who is stronger than he.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there are many things multiplying vanity; what advantage [is] to man?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For who knoweth what [is] good for a man in life, the number of the days of the life of his vanity, and he maketh them as a shadow? for who declareth to man what is after him under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better [is] a name than good perfume, And the day of death than the day of birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better to go unto a house of mourning, Than to go unto a house of banqueting, For that is the end of all men, And the living layeth [it] unto his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better [is] sorrow than laughter, For by the sadness of the face the heart becometh better.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The heart of the wise [is] in a house of mourning, And the heart of fools in a house of mirth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better to hear a rebuke of a wise man, Than [for] a man to hear a song of fools,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For as the noise of thorns under the pot, So [is] the laughter of a fool, even this [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Surely oppression maketh the wise mad, And a gift destroyeth the heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better [is] the latter end of a thing than its beginning, Better [is] the patient of spirit, than the haughty of spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be not hasty in thy spirit to be angry, For anger in the bosom of fools resteth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say not thou, `What was it, That the former days were better than these?' For thou hast not asked wisely of this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wisdom [is] good with an inheritance, And an advantage [it is] to those beholding the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For wisdom [is] a defense, money [is] a defence, And the advantage of the knowledge of wisdom [is], She reviveth her possessors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See the work of God, For who is able to make straight that which He made crooked?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In a day of prosperity be in gladness, And in a day of evil consider. Also this over-against that hath God made, To the intent that man doth not find anything after him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole I have considered in the days of my vanity. There is a righteous one perishing in his righteousness, and there is a wrong-doer prolonging [himself] in his wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be not over-righteous, nor show thyself too wise, why art thou desolate?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not much wrong, neither be thou a fool, why dost thou die within thy time?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: [It is] good that thou dost lay hold on this, and also, from that withdrawest not thy hand, for whoso is fearing God goeth out with them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wisdom giveth strength to a wise man, more than wealth the rulers who have been in a city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because there is not a righteous man on earth that doth good and sinneth not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also to all the words that they speak give not thy heart, that thou hear not thy servant reviling thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For many times also hath thy heart known that thou thyself also hast reviled others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All this I have tried by wisdom; I have said, `I am wise,' and it [is] far from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Far off [is] that which hath been, and deep, deep, who doth find it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have turned round, also my heart, to know and to search, and to seek out wisdom, and reason, and to know the wrong of folly, and of foolishness the madness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I am finding more bitter than death, the woman whose heart [is] nets and snares, her hands [are] bands; the good before God escapeth from her, but the sinner is captured by her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See, this I have found, said the Preacher, one to one, to find out the reason
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (that still my soul had sought, and I had not found), One man, a teacher, I have found, and a woman among all these I have not found.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See, this alone I have found, that God made man upright, and they -- they have sought out many devices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who [is] as the wise? and who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? The wisdom of man causeth his face to shine, and the hardness of his face is changed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I pray thee, the commandment of a king keep, even for the sake of the oath of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be not troubled at his presence, thou mayest go, stand not in an evil thing, for all that he pleaseth he doth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where the word of a king [is] power [is], and who saith to him, `What dost thou?'
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoso is keeping a command knoweth no evil thing, and time and judgment the heart of the wise knoweth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For to every delight there is a time and a judgment, for the misfortune of man is great upon him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he knoweth not that which shall be, for when it shall be who declareth to him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is no man ruling over the spirit to restrain the spirit, and there is no authority over the day of death, and there is no discharge in battle, and wickedness delivereth not its possessors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All this I have seen so as to give my heart to every work that hath been done under the sun; a time that man hath ruled over man to his own evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so I have seen the wicked buried, and they went in, even from the Holy Place they go, and they are forgotten in the city whether they had so done. This also [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because sentence hath not been done [on] an evil work speedily, therefore the heart of the sons of man is full within them to do evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Though a sinner is doing evil a hundred [times], and prolonging [himself] for it, surely also I know that there is good to those fearing God, who fear before Him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And good is not to the wicked, and he doth not prolong days as a shadow, because he is not fearing before God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is a vanity that hath been done upon the earth, that there are righteous ones unto whom it is coming according to the work of the wicked, and there are wicked ones unto whom it is coming according to the work of the righteous. I have said that this also [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I have praised mirth because there is no good to man under the sun except to eat and to drink, and to rejoice, and it remaineth with him of his labour the days of his life that God hath given to him under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I gave my heart to know wisdom and to see the business that hath been done on the earth, (for there is also a spectator in whose eyes sleep is not by day and by night),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I considered all the work of God, that man is not able to find out the work that hath been done under the sun, because though man labour to seek, yet he doth not find; and even though the wise man speak of knowing he is not able to find.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But all this I have laid unto my heart, so as to clear up the whole of this, that the righteous and the wise, and their works, [are] in the hand of God, neither love nor hatred doth man know, the whole [is] before them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole [is] as to the whole; one event is to the righteous and to the wicked, to the good, and to the clean, and to the unclean, and to him who is sacrificing, and to him who is not sacrificing; as [is] the good, so [is] the sinner, he who is swearing as he who is fearing an oath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This [is] an evil among all that hath been done under the sun, that one event [is] to all, and also the heart of the sons of man is full of evil, and madness [is] in their heart during their life, and after it -- unto the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But [to] him who is joined unto all the living there is confidence, for to a living dog it [is] better than to the dead lion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the living know that they die, and the dead know not anything, and there is no more to them a reward, for their remembrance hath been forgotten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their love also, their hatred also, their envy also, hath already perished, and they have no more a portion to the age in all that hath been done under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go, eat with joy thy bread, and drink with a glad heart thy wine, for already hath God been pleased with thy works.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At all times let thy garments be white, and let not perfume be lacking on thy head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See life with the wife whom thou hast loved, all the days of the life of thy vanity, that He hath given to thee under the sun, all the days of thy vanity, for it [is] thy portion in life, even of thy labour that thou art labouring at under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All that thy hand findeth to do, with thy power do, for there is no work, and device, and knowledge, and wisdom in Sheol whither thou art going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have turned so as to see under the sun, that not to the swift [is] the race, nor to the mighty the battle, nor even to the wise bread, nor even to the intelligent wealth, nor even to the skilful grace, for time and chance happen with them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For even man knoweth not his time; as fish that are taken hold of by an evil net, and as birds that are taken hold of by a snare, like these [are] the sons of man snared at an evil time, when it falleth upon them suddenly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This also I have seen: wisdom under the sun, and it is great to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A little city, and few men in it, and a great king hath come unto it, and hath surrounded it, and hath built against it great bulwarks;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and there hath been found in it a poor wise man, and he hath delivered the city by his wisdom, and men have not remembered that poor man!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I said, `Better [is] wisdom than might, and the wisdom of the poor is despised, and his words are not heard.' --
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of the wise in quiet are heard, More than the cry of a ruler over fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better [is] wisdom than weapons of conflict, And one sinner destroyeth much good!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dead flies cause a perfumer's perfume To send forth a stink; The precious by reason of wisdom -- By reason of honour -- a little folly!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The heart of the wise [is] at his right hand, And the heart of a fool at his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And also, when he that is a fool Is walking in the way, his heart is lacking, And he hath said to every one, `He [is] a fool.'
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the spirit of the ruler go up against thee, Thy place leave not, For yielding quieteth great sinners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is an evil I have seen under the sun, As an error that goeth out from the ruler,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He hath set the fool in many high places, And the rich in a low place do sit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen servants on horses, And princes walking as servants on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoso is digging a pit falleth into it, And whoso is breaking a hedge, a serpent biteth him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoso is removing stones is grieved by them, Whoso is cleaving trees endangered by them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the iron hath been blunt, And he the face hath not sharpened, Then doth he increase strength, And wisdom [is] advantageous to make right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the serpent biteth without enchantment, Then there is no advantage to a master of the tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Words of the mouth of the wise [are] gracious, And the lips of a fool swallow him up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The beginning of the words of his mouth [is] folly, And the latter end of his mouth [Is] mischievous madness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the fool multiplieth words: `Man knoweth not that which is, And that which is after him, who doth declare to him?'
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The labour of the foolish wearieth him, In that he hath not known to go unto the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wo to thee, O land, when thy king [is] a youth, And thy princes do eat in the morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Happy art thou, O land, When thy king [is] a son of freemen, And thy princes do eat in due season, For might, and not for drunkenness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By slothfulness is the wall brought low, And by idleness of the hands doth the house drop.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For mirth they are making a feast, And wine maketh life joyful, And the silver answereth with all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even in thy mind a king revile not, And in the inner parts of thy bed-chamber Revile not the rich: For a fowl of the heavens causeth the voice to go, And a possessor of wings declareth the word.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Send forth thy bread on the face of the waters, For in the multitude of the days thou dost find it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give a portion to seven, and even to eight, For thou knowest not what evil is on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the thick clouds are full of rain, On the earth they empty [themselves]; And if a tree doth fall in the south or to the north, The place where the tree falleth, there it is.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoso is observing the wind soweth not, And whoso is looking on the thick clouds reapeth not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As thou knowest not what [is] the way of the spirit, How -- bones in the womb of the full one, So thou knowest not the work of God who maketh the whole.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning sow thy seed, And at even withdraw not thy hand, For thou knowest not which is right, this or that, Or whether both of them alike [are] good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sweet also [is] the light, And good for the eyes to see the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But, if man liveth many years, In all of them let him rejoice, And remember the days of darkness, For they are many! all that is coming [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rejoice, O young man, in thy childhood, And let thy heart gladden thee in days of thy youth, And walk in the ways of thy heart, And in the sight of thine eyes, And know thou that for all these, Doth God bring thee into judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And turn aside anger from thy heart, And cause evil to pass from thy flesh, For the childhood and the age [are] vanity!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember also thy Creators in days of thy youth, While that the evil days come not, Nor the years have arrived, that thou sayest, `I have no pleasure in them.'
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While that the sun is not darkened, and the light, And the moon, and the stars, And the thick clouds returned after the rain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the day that keepers of the house tremble, And men of strength have bowed themselves, And grinders have ceased, because they have become few. And those looking out at the windows have become dim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And doors have been shut in the street. When the noise of the grinding is low, And [one] riseth at the voice of the bird, And all daughters of song are bowed down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also of that which is high they are afraid, And of the low places in the way, And the almond-tree is despised, And the grasshopper is become a burden, And want is increased, For man is going unto his home age-during, And the mourners have gone round through the street.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While that the silver cord is not removed, And the golden bowl broken, And the pitcher broken by the fountain, And the wheel broken at the well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the dust returneth to the earth as it was, And the spirit returneth to God who gave it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Vanity of vanities, said the preacher, the whole [is] vanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And further, because the preacher was wise, he still taught the people knowledge, and gave ear, and sought out -- he made right many similes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The preacher sought to find out pleasing words, and, written [by] the upright, words of truth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Words of the wise [are] as goads, and as fences planted [by] the masters of collections, they have been given by one shepherd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And further, from these, my son, be warned; the making of many books hath no end, and much study [is] a weariness of the flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The end of the whole matter let us hear: -- `Fear God, and keep His commands, for this [is] the whole of man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For every work doth God bring into judgment, with every hidden thing, whether good or bad.'
verses.speaker: Narrator
